name: Marshall House

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The Marshall House is NOT a trendy, new-wave hotel. It was built in the 1800's - how could it be? But it is not lacking, in the least, of your typical, everyday comforts. The Marshall House is a wonderful hotel, with a great staff and tons of old world charm.
reviews.title: Charming

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The hotel is very easy to locate and is in a great location - you can walk anywhere. The hotel itself is very clean and the rooms are large. The bathroom is also clean with plenty of towels, lots of room to move, good water pressure and nice bath products. The staff went out of their way to be helpful. My husband and I recieved lots of suggestions for restaurants, places to see and things to do (not that Savannah is lacking in any of the previously mentioned).
reviews.title: Not What it Looks Like
Charmed in Savannah
reviews.text: The evening wine and cheese reception is a wonderful touch, as is the breakfast in the morning.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: My husband and I WILL stay there again - soon!
reviews.title: Okay, but leaves something to be desired

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Although it prides itself on being quaint and not for modern travelers, we thought the Marshall House was more than old-fashioned, it was old, dirty, and we even found a cobweb in the corner of the room. The staff is rude, and the sheets were rough. We would not tell friends to travel and stay here. Although, Savannah itself was beautiful!
reviews.title: This hotel is probably not for everyone

reviews.text: I stayed here with a friend in mid-October. The room was very nice, clean. The bed was very comfortable. The service was first-rate. The price was not cheap, but I would definitely stay there again. It was my first visit to Savannah and I could not have asked for a better location- downtown, bordering the Historic district. The complimentary breakfast , including quiche, was a very nice touch. Even the hotel bar became quite interesting at night. Although touristy, the riverfront was a fun place to people-watch, it was quite lively. We had a superb meal at Elizabeth's on 37th. Soho South Cafe was a great lunch place with a artful surroundings. Casimir's Lounge, at Mansion on Forsyth , was a beautiful bar with a nice little jazz group. Gallery Espresso on Bull St. was a perfect place to linger outside across from one of the many Squares, with coffee or wine....Loved Marshall House, and loved Savannah..
reviews.title: One of the Best...

likes.liked: — It was a first rate hotel

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2002, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: A lot of history at this old army hospital-turned-hotel. Right in the historic district so we walked everywhere we wanted to go, and the price was right. I would definitely stay here again.
reviews.title: A neat stay.

likes.disliked: — If you like ghosts, this is the place for you!

reviews.text: After an initial trip to Savannah with my wife to see friends back in August, I recently needed to go back on business. I tried to stay in the same quaint little property called the Gastonian but they were full on the dates I needed. They recommended their sister property, The Marshall House. I was extremely pleased with this hotel as well. Very convenient to downtown Savannah and very adequately furnished for the business traveler. The high speed Internet service has very much appreciated. The staff were very courteous and helpful with directions and the restaurant, 45 Bristo, was excellent. It certainly is a well kept secret for the business traveler. Try it out!
reviews.title: Best kept secrets in Savannah

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stayed two nights at the Marshall House for our 20th anniversary. We made the mistake of booking a package from their hotel web site. It looked like we were purchasing a package, but were in fact only reserving a room. The checkout screen made no mention of the fact that the rate that was presented was before taxes. This added $70 to the package price. It turns out that this disclaimer is burried at the bottom of an intermediate screen. When we called to discuss this problem, the night manager said that we were not the first people to experience this problem and that the web site confusion was a known probem, but that he did not have the authority to address the problem. When I spoke to the day shift manager, he was adamant that the hotel would do nothing to recify the situation.
reviews.title: Beware of the rip off

reviews.text: As to the hotel itself:
reviews.title: Neat Historic Hotel, Great Location

reviews.text: Maybe I stayed at a different hotel than the people who wrote such glowing reviews of this hotel. The reviewers must be employees of the Marshal House. Our stay was miserable.
reviews.title: Iffy At Best
Perfectly located
reviews.text: The staff is completely useless. Every request was met with a rude refusal. I called the concierge three times on Friday, to request a gift for the room of a friend, I finally got a response on Sunday. No one seemed to be able to do anything.

reviews.title: Nice hotel in a perfect location
reviews.text: There seemed to be some type of machinery room above our room. The noise started at 4:00AM, every morning. The front desk, as usual, couldn't do anything about it.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I can understand the staff not being able to get us tickets for certain tours, but their rudeness was unacceptable. Everyone at this hotel seems to be having very unhappy lives. Too bad they take it out on their guests.
reviews.title: Nice hotel

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Look elsewhere, Savanah is too nice to spend your time and money at this hotel.
reviews.title: Loved the hotel

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I need to preface this review by saying that the staff is extremely nice and helpful. Our departing flight was cancelled at the last minute due to weather. The gentleman I spoke with at the front desk was more than happy to move up our check-in and check-out time by one day. When I asked if there would be any fee for the change he replied that it wasn't our fault, there would be no charge, and he was happy to help us. On another day (we stayed a total of 4) the front desk helped us with information we needed to get to Bonaventure Cemetery. We didn't have a car, so we took the number 10 bus and walked the 1/3 mile down Bonaventure Road and needed their opinion of the safety of the street (it was fine and $40 cheaper to take the bus than to take a cab ($4 total for 2 to get there and back)).
reviews.title: Nice enough hotel for the price but on one of the loudest streets in Savannah!

likes.disliked: — The insane noise from the busy street and the terrible wine

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: That said, the room's interior was nice enough for the price. There is a safe, which is great to leave your valuables in. There is also a mini-fridge, which is a nice touch though we didn't use it. The bed was not the most comfortable, but that could just be because we're used to a firmer bed. The pillows were cotton but comfortable (no feather pillows), and the sheets were fine--not luxury, but this isn't a luxury hotel. The robes were very light and not very comfortable compared to other hotel robes we have used in the past but better than nothing. The room was clean and had more atmosphere than a chain hotel would have had and it was about $50-$100 less a night than the B&Bs we had looked into. HOWEVER, we were in a room on the top floor, right on East Broughton Street. It is an extremely busy street with buses, large trucks, and motorcyles/cars (often with radios blaring) constantly going by in large number from very early in the morning until evening. We live in Manhattan--we are used to loud! This street made our NYC street seem downright quiet and peaceful in contrast! I highly, highly suggest that you bring earplugs--if you need quiet to sleep this is not the place. The street does slow down in the evening, but it starts again very early the next morning! Perhaps the rooms off of Broughton (of which there are few) are more quiet, I don't know. If you get one of the 2nd floor rooms with viranda you'll be gazing down at the before-mentioned busy street and an H&R Block, cellular phone store, etc. directly across the way. We were very glad that we didn't pay extra for the viranda room.
reviews.title: Not what I expected

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The hotel lobby and hallways are very nice. The hotel has a rich history and it is worth the time to walk up and down the hallways of each floor to look at the artwork, history, and artifacts found during the hotel's remodeling. Each floor's hallways contain images and pieces from different times in Savannah's history.
reviews.title: Perfect!!!

likes.liked: — This location and the historic ambience of the hotel - also the restaurant - 45 Bistro
likes.disliked: — honestly don't have a dislike - loved it all - even the ghosts

reviews.title: Wouldn't go back
reviews.text: The breakfast was great the first day, okay the second and third days, and mundane by the fourth day. The quiche Lorraine was delicious (at least at first), but the spinach quiche was tasteless. They had biscuits and a variety of muffins, danishes, bagels, cereals, etc. (some days the variety was better than others). They also offered fresh fruit, yogurt, a variety of juices, teas, and, of course, coffee. The breakfast room's decor is reminiscent of a retirement home dining room in Boca Raton-- go figure since the rest of the hotel is decorated so nicely.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The wine hour was, for lack of a better word, bland. 3 varieties of wine, but the wine was a label we were not familiar with and for good reason--if you know anything about wine, the wine is pretty terrible. The crackers and cheese cubes (cheddar, swiss, and occasionally jalepeno something-or-other) were not exactly gourmet--but, again, this isn't a luxury hotel, you get what you pay for. Another reviewer said that the area was dirty, but we found the lobby area (where the wine and cheese was served) to always be clean and very comfortable.
reviews.title: Outstanding

description: The Marshall House. Originally built as the first hotel in our fair city, this is one of the most unique boutique hotels in Savannah. Offering 68 guest rooms and a perfect downtown location on Broughton Street, The Marshall House is ideally situated right in the heart of Savannah's historic district. Coastal Living magazine named The Marshall House among its top 20 favorite lodgings, and the Travel Channel featured The Marshall House on its "Great Hotels" program. Original windows, pinewood floors and claw-foot tubs in some rooms are among the charming attributes that make The Marshall House one of the most popular Savannah historic inns. Guests especially enjoy the suite that opens onto a classic wrought-iron veranda complete with rocking chairs and ceiling fans. This hotel is a participant in our Guest Rewards Program.
